terrain.desc: A 15% grade on technical rock is slower than 15% on fire road. We account for surface efficiency and technicality.

disclaimer.title: Not a Crystal Ball.
disclaimer.text: This is a planning instrument. The output assumes optimal execution and conditions. Weather, nutrition failures, and injury are variables you must manage on race day. We provide the strategy; you provide the execution.

privacy.title: Privacy and Data
privacy.body1: GPX Analyzer uses your Strava data only to build your performance model and improve prediction accuracy. I do not sell or share your personal data with third parties.
privacy.body2: You can disconnect Strava at any time. If you request data removal, I will delete your stored profile and simulations.

privacy.contact_link: Contact me from the Who I am page

howitworks.title: How GPX Analyzer Works
howitworks.subtitle: A physics-first model that learns from your data to predict how you actually run on trails.

tiers.title: Progressive Learning System
tiers.intro: The more activities you share, the more accurate your predictions become. The system automatically advances through three tiers as it learns your running profile.

tier1.title: Physics Baseline
tier1.text: Uses biomechanical principles to predict pace based on terrain gradient. Models how energy cost changes with hill steepness, differentiating between uphill (energy-limited) and downhill (technique-limited) running.

tier2.title: Personalized Physics
tier2.text: Learns your individual running characteristics. Optimizes model parameters to match your actual performance patterns - your climbing efficiency, downhill technique, and how fatigue affects you over distance.

tier3.title: Physics + Machine Learning
tier3.text: Combines personalized physics with adaptive ML corrections. Learns subtle patterns that pure physics cannot capture: terrain roughness effects, your response to grade transitions, and cumulative fatigue on different terrain types.

learning.title: What We Learn From Your Data

uphill.title: Uphill Efficiency
uphill.text: How well you climb relative to the average runner. Some athletes are natural climbers, others prefer flats.

downhill.title: Downhill Technique
downhill.text: Your comfort and speed on descents. Technical ability and risk tolerance vary significantly between runners.

fatigue.title: Fatigue Response
fatigue.text: How your pace degrades as you accumulate distance and elevation. Critical for ultra-distance predictions.

baseline.title: Baseline Speed
baseline.text: Your flat-terrain pace that anchors all predictions. Everything else is calculated relative to this.

physics.title: Physics Foundation
physics.text: The core model is built on biomechanical research. Uphill running increases metabolic energy cost exponentially with gradient. Downhill running is limited by technique - gravity helps, but braking and foot control become the bottleneck. We also model eccentric fatigue: downhill running causes cumulative muscle damage that reduces performance in subsequent sections.

effort.title: Effort Level Adjustments
effort.intro: Predictions adapt to your intended effort. The confidence interval shifts based on whether you are racing, training, or recovering.

privacy.title: Your Data Stays Yours
privacy.text: All learning happens exclusively on your individual data. No cross-user patterns, no crowd-sourced models. Your performance profile is unique to your account and cannot be accessed or transferred.

about.title: Edoardo Gabrielli
about.subtitle: Trail runner, physics and software developer.
about.body1: I'm an amateur trail runner and a software developer with a physics background. In this project I apply modeling and data analysis to turn GPX tracks into actionable race-planning guidance.
about.body2: I developed GPX Analyzer to solve the gaps I felt in race planning, and now I share it with the community.
about.personal_title: Built from my own training, refined for yours.
about.personal_text: It began as a personal tool for long mountain days, then evolved into something other athletes could use with the same honesty and precision.
